response was still irrational. "We are here to discuss how four Americans

the one who brought up the issue about 'most Muslims', not us." Well, the 
question put to the panel was what America is doing in terms of taking on 
the ideology that motivates these attacks, so her question was 100% 
directly on point.

right-wingers that the peaceful Muslims were being silent in their 
condemnation of terrorism. One day I decided to check, suspecting 
(correctly) that their "common knowledge" position was bullshit (as it 
usually is on the Right). Sure enough, after finding a list of the largest 
Muslim orgs in the USA, all of them had explicit condemnations of 9-11 and 
terrorism as a tactic. All the North Africa, Middle East, Asia, and Oceania 
nations of the Muslim world condemned 9-11, including Iran if I recall - 
with the exception of Iraq.
CAIR even bothered to summarize their many deeds of silence on the issue of 
terrorism: https://www.cair.com/about-us/cair-anti-terrorism-campaigns.html
This is just another manifestation of the pathetic fact-free conservative 
bubble. Once the clowns on right-wing talk radio, and Fox, and the blogs, 
start acting as if *anything* is a self-evident fact, then the legions of 
right-wing morons will also accept it as fact, without any reflection, no 
matter how absurd. The bubble is a very real thing, and indicates the 
terrifying level of control that the agenda setters can exercise over the 
weak-minded and ignorant right-wing followers.

4. The comments and examples about peaceful-but-ineffectual majorities were 
basically correct, but also irrelevant as a comparison to Islamic 
terrorism. That's because the examples given were all the actions of 
*States*; a wicked group or person gained political control, and so had the

When I re-watched the video dispassionately, and whilst disagreeing with 
everything which related to Bengazi and being an American (ranty delivery 
notwithstanding and shouting aside), I couldn't find fault with what 
Brigitte Gabriel actually said about the historical numbers of deaths in 
those historical times, and that peaceful people didn't actually matter in 
the equation.Naturally, I also don't actually agree with her numbers of 
radical Muslims in the world - I think it is far lower than that. I do, 
however, think that it is in the tens of millions.

However, even though I agreed with the comparison of Islamism to those 
other barbaric historical movements, I cannot understand why they felt that 
this woman's question did not deserve to be answered. I fully support the 
fight against Islamists in various ways, but I am not stupid enough to 
think that we are going to win this very long battle without some sort of 
better ideology on the offer. It was an absolutely relevant question which 
deserved to be answered. It not only deserves an answer, but requires it.

We did win the war against Nazi Germany and Imperial Japan by bombing the 
hell out of them (and I am not advocating that we ever do that again to 
anyone), but we had a huge investment afterwards in not only rebuilding 
their entire infrastructure, but also starting an entire *real* democracy 
in each place from scratch. This included recreating entire institutions, 
giving free education, and giving them a moral groundwork from which to 
proceed later on. And while I am not certain that this would actually work 
in many parts of the Middle East today, as evidenced by what is currently 
happening in Iraq, at least there *should* be an answer to the question 
posed.

I also found the response to her question quite rude. I may disagree with 
this woman on many different fundamental levels ranging from philosophy and 
religious world views (I'm an atheist, after all), but she was extremely 
polite in asking her valid question and deserved far better treatment than 
to be publicly insulted and humiliated in such a reprehensible way.

I think that the Heritage Foundation owes her a public apology.﻿
